all she would get is-- because

1446.93.text:
you've been wronged and you're
trying to explain yourself

1449.30.text:
on social media-- everyone
goes, "Oh, now she's saying--"

1454.22.text:
The only thing to do if you're
Justine Sacco-- and this

1458.20.text:
is what we don't want to
do as human beings-- is

1468.71.text:
We did have a
question over here--

1472.64.text:
I know I'm sounding cross
here, but I am really not

1476.01.text:
Because for the first
time since public shaming

1480.04.text:
was stopped in the mid-19th
century for being too brutal,

1484.60.text:
we have been given
the opportunity

1486.91.text:
to decide the severity
of people's fates.

1489.50.text: And what did we decide to do?

1490.71.text:
Be [BLEEP] hanging judges, to
be the people in the lithographs

1500.57.text:
To me, the problem
we have right now,

1502.11.text:
we have a very sort
of intolerant society

1504.02.text:
where people don't want to
actually argue and take you

1508.77.text:
It's rather they'd
just slag you off.

1510.31.text:
And I think equally
the problem we have is

1512.23.text:
that people are getting
arrested for this stuff now.

1514.77.text:
And as my friend
Adam Curtis says,

1517.59.text:
Twitter is designed as a kind
of mutual approval machine.

1520.85.text:
Adam calls it "mutual grooming,"
where we surround ourselves

1523.67.text:
with people who feel
exactly the same way we do.

1526.41.text:
And if somebody comes along
who doesn't agree with us,

1530.02.text:
we kind of scream them
out-- which I fully

1531.89.text:
understand is kind
of what I just

1532.71.text: did to you, so I apologise.

1536.01.text:
And it's partly because I
didn't have much to eat.

1539.91.text:
But what that is,
as you just said,

1541.88.text:
when you surround yourself
with people who feel exactly

1544.17.text:
the same way you do and refuse
to listen to anybody who

1546.76.text:
has a different point of view,
what that is the opposite of

1550.98.text:
And the point is
everybody in my book,

1553.79.text:
including Justine Sacco,
did something wrong.

1558.91.text:
We have created a
world for ourselves

1560.52.text:
where we are defined on social
media by the worst thing

1564.49.text:
that we ever did,
by our worst tweets,

1567.86.text:
That's not the world
I want to live in.

1569.48.text:
You said at the beginning we're
trying to think about the world

1571.58.text: that we want to live in.

1572.30.text:
The world I want to
live in is the world

1574.19.text:
where everybody-- and we know
this about human beings--

1577.54.text:
everybody is a mixture of
talents and sins and wisdom

1584.06.text:
And when somebody's mistake is
put in a wider human context--

1588.18.text:
which is something that social
media has forgotten how to do,

1590.72.text:
by and large-- that's the
world that I want to live in.
